raw_comment:
This relates to me and my community because I'm currently a junior, soon-to-be rising senior, who's likely going to start having to apply to colleges later this year, and I am by no means a legacy applicant or of legacy status, and neither are many of my current acquaintances. I can say that I'm already fortunate enough to have grown up privileged and never "poor", but nevertheless, I am far from "rich" in terms of income rank, and according to this graph, that will also unfortunately affect my chances of being accepted into more elite and prestigious colleges. 

Catchy Headline: Smarts or Status?: Advantages of Legacy & Affluent Applicants 

Pt. 2- Questions 3 & 4
ace_sentences: This topic relates to me and my community.
I am currently a junior in high school.
I will soon be a rising senior.
Later this year, I will probably apply to colleges.
I am not a legacy applicant.
I do not have legacy status.
Many of my current acquaintances are not legacy applicants.
My income rank is far from rich.
The graph shows that income rank affects the chance of acceptance to elite colleges.
My income rank will unfortunately affect my chance of acceptance to elite and prestigious colleges.
The headline is: Smarts or Status?: Advantages of Legacy and Affluent Applicants.
This comment relates to questions 3 and 4.
